cards.front: In a parallel connection, what does KVL force?
cards.back: All branch voltages equal the port voltage: v = v1 = v2. Every element in parallel sees the same voltage.

cards.front: In a parallel connection, what does KCL give?
cards.back: The port current equals the sum of all branch currents: i = i1 + i2.

cards.front: State the parallel addition rule for voltage-controlled resistors.
cards.back: If i1 = i-hat1(v) and i2 = i-hat2(v), the parallel combination gives i = i-hat1(v) + i-hat2(v). The result is also voltage-controlled.
At each voltage value, add the currents from each curve. In the v-i plane, this is vertical stacking: the combined curve sits above either individual curve at every voltage level.

cards.front: State four key dual pairs in circuit theory.
cards.back: Voltage <-> Current. KVL <-> KCL. Resistance <-> Conductance. Series <-> Parallel. (Also: voltage source <-> current source, open circuit <-> short circuit, mesh <-> node.)

cards.front: What is the dual of 'series connection of current-controlled resistors is current-controlled'?
cards.back: Parallel connection of voltage-controlled resistors is voltage-controlled. (Swap series<->parallel and current-controlled<->voltage-controlled.)

cards.front: What is the dual of inductance L?
cards.back: Capacitance C. In the duality transformation, inductance and capacitance are swapped.

cards.front: What is the dual of a Thevenin equivalent?
cards.back: A Norton equivalent. Thevenin (voltage source + series resistance) is dual to Norton (current source + parallel conductance).

cards.front: For two linear resistors in parallel, what is the equivalent resistance?
cards.back: R_eq = R1*R2/(R1+R2), or equivalently G_eq = G1+G2. Conductances add in parallel, just as resistances add in series.

cards.front: What is the dual of an open circuit?
cards.back: A short circuit. An open circuit has i = 0 for all v; its dual (a short circuit) has v = 0 for all i.
